Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example:
ʤe:r etike-r
two old.man-PL
‘two old men’

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example:
erek ariŋkïl
this devil
‘these devils’

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Example:
ammu-da eŋmu-da horritïn
father-COM mother-COM come
‘Father and mother have come.’

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Comment: neither in pronouns nor in verbs

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Example:
ŋin-ïl
dog-PL
‘dogs’

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
ami-ja
father-ASSOC
‘father and his relatives’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Example:
tanї-n
read-NMLZ
‘reading’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Example:
etu-mŋї
guard-NMLZ
‘a guard’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Example:
hir-tiŋ
cut-NMLZ
‘a segment’

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
bej aj
person good
‘a good person’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Example:
aj bej
good person
‘a good person’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Example:
o:-dï
become-NONFUT
‘They are becoming.’
haa-rï
know-NONFUT
‘They know.’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Example:
emdihnïn
come
‘they have come’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Detailed comment:
there are two future tenses: definite and indefinite
definite: -ʤi, -či, -te
indefinite: -ʤiŋa, -čiŋa, -ʤiŋe, -čiŋe
Example:
bo:-ʤene-vu
give.back-FUT.INDEF-1SG
‘I will give back.’

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
bii hin-duk egʤe-tmïr bihï-m
1SG 2SG-ABL high-COMP be-1SG
‘I am taller than you.’
umbe-du bolïhï-ŋhi-vur ho:jav ujamkam ʤeptit
Umbe-DAT autumn-SIM-1PL many mountain.sheep eat.PST
‘When we spent the autumn in Umbe, we ate many mountain sheep.’

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
bo:-ʤene-vu
give.back-FUT.INDEF-1SG
‘I will give back.’

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Comment: “Like other Tungusic languages (cf. Stojnova 2016, to appear), the North Tungusic languages have an associated motion suffix –nA that expresses mainly andative meanings, but can have ventive readings as well. This adds a directional argument to the argument structure.” Lebedev (1978:38-105): there is marking indicating a reverse action: bring - bring back

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Detailed comment: tense markers depend on the conjugation class

Feature: Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Example:
i:-v-deji
enter-CAUS-PTCP
‘carry in’

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Example:
bej-čeke-r iken-met-te
person-?-PL sing-RECIP-?
‘People are praising each other.’

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Comment: the S argument is usually omitted
Example:
ʤigïnmier murïŋ emčel
forty horse come.PST
‘(We) came on forty horses.’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?

Example:
umbe-du bolïhï-ŋhi-vur ho:jav ujamkam ʤeptit
Umbe-DAT autumn-SIM-1PL many mountain.sheep eat.PST
‘When we spent the autumn in Umbe, we ate many mountain sheep.’

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Example:

‘Don’t give!’
no examples for declarative negation available

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?

Example:
maa-v-daji
kill-PASS-IND

bak-u-daji
find-PASS-IND

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Comment: there is a marker in Lamunkhin and Bystraja dialects of Even
Example:
ee, kuŋa bi-hiŋi-j buollar upeː-je-ŋ-čel 
eh child be-VS.IPFV-PRFL.SG DP.Y grandmother-ASSOC-ALN-COM 
bi-j-deg-im=diː 
be-CONN-ASS.Y-1SG.Y=EMPH.Y 
‘When I was a child I lived with my grandmother and her family.’

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Detailed comment:
participles:
-ŋhi SIM
-riʤi SEQ (event happened before another one)
Example:
umbe-du bolïhï-ŋhi-vur ho:jav ujamkam ʤeptit
Umbe-DAT autumn-SIM-1PL many mountain.sheep eat.PST
‘When we spent the autumn in Umbe, we ate many mountain sheep.’
emd-iʤi itïg-ŋendi
come-SEQ prepare-?
‘Prepare (it), when you have come.’

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Comment: there are no examples with transitive verbs available

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?

Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?

Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?

Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Example:
erek ariŋkïl
this devil
‘these devils’

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?

Feature: Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?

Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Example:
aj bej
good person
‘a good person’

Example:

deer-PL-3SG all-3SG 3SG

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Detailed comment:
bekïč ‘all’
e:jdu ‘whole, all’
butun ‘all’ (from Yakut)
bejten ‘every’
Example:
orï-l-ni bekïč-ïn noŋïn
deer-PL-3SG all-3SG 3SG
‘all his deer’

rich-LOC man-LOC whose-? all be-?

1SG 2SG-ABL high-COMP be-1SG

Feature: Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?

Example:
umbe-du bolïhï-ŋhi-vur ho:jav ujamkam ʤeptit
Umbe-DAT autumn-SIM-1PL many mountain.sheep eat.PST

two old.man-PL
